Review Text: Small minded, micro managed, no opportunities to progress unless you're family. Lack of upskilling opportunities.
The politics of construction

Company culture & behaviour is lacking and so is the professionalism. Every BU is its own clique. Collaboration & knowledge sharing are alien concepts. Staff would rather remain in their own silos and gossip about each other instead of achieving meaningful work together.
Constantly micromanaged and a lack of investment in system and IT improving efficiencies and communications.

Very Noisy , no real opportunity to get to know any other staff during work hours, fast paced, repetitive and joyless. Training is very much on the job - with no proper trainer or training regime - just other staff used to teach new staff. For example I was there less than 3 months, and still learning things myself when I was teamed up with a new staff member and expected to teach them. So no uniformity with training at all. Also - asking for a day off whilst still in your probation period was met with hostility from floor manager. Being sick was also frowned upon. Its all about the work & the Output- regardless of the health/safety of staff. Its one of those places that will say they are doing everything to keep people safe - but really they are really just doing the legal minimum ( and perhaps sometimes less). Any suggestions to make something better or safer for staff are ignored if it would reduce the output.

As with all businesses, the challenge of navigating the export side of business it was quite tricky at times. I think better ways of communication could have been implemented in order to achieve the best outcome.

There are always challenges in most things we do. Navigating through them to achieve a positive outcome. Continuously looking for qualified staff, Finding the balance to be cost competitive and selling a project.
Learn all parts of the business Manufacture quality parts Achieve kpi
When the company got busy, managing what gets done first can be challenging.
Family owned business that cares only about profit
Working with old technology, red tape, change management and old school culture.
heavy workload, no management support

No challenges at all

At first having passions to build things together but in time getting explained bye different people

Management is lacking in any skill. There is no HR, it’s a mans business with no opportunity for career progression. They are very backwards in their business approach.
You have to keep to the target and stay focus when you do the job.
Zero trust in anything outside of what the head management can conceive and since they've all been there for 25 years plus, consider innovation and forward thinking at an incredibly low bar.

Management not listening to their staff and poor communication
Location is in Tullamarine so it's far out from the city but there is a bus that stops right out the front and everyone gets a car space. The travel is worth the job.
The office is located in Tullamarine which isn't close to the city however there is no traffic to and from work!

Coming into the company at a very transitional time for the business as it was about to roll out a complete business remodel was particularly challenging and not the ideal time to join any business.
Try to work out what the management want.
Management and company culture
They like to make you work a lot of hours no matter what and if you don't they out cast you. In my experience the more hours you do it's not enough.
Paid a salary and then you are expected to stop your life and work continuously. Expected to work very early hours , long days and then Saturdays. Glad they let me go.

Since the merge ABN has become very bureaucratic with a high staff turnover. We now see lots of team leaders and managers in roles they may not be experienced enough for. There is no accountability on departments and too many responsibilities now lie with the construction team.

ABN Group is a fast-paced, ever-changing workplace. Not for everyone, some people don't like the constant change and expectation to rise to the standard. There certainly is a culture of working hard but with the right managers, it doesn't go unnoticed by leadership and is paid off with many perks.
There has been a reliance on traditional processes, and some initial hesitation around change - however, this is gradually shifting.

Being a larger business, there has been times when collaboration between departments has been challenging, but the groups focus on continual learning and improvement has meant this is being addressed as part of the current business plan.
Nothing major. Pay is average to start with.

There seems to be little room for growth or advancement within the company, which can be demotivating for long-term career planning. Salary is not competitive compared to similar roles in the industry, which may not align with the effort and pace of the work environment. The fast-paced environment, while engaging, can sometimes lead to burnout or difficulty maintaining a healthy work-life balance. Limited training opportunities and a lack of focus on personal or professional development can make it hard to upskill or feel valued. Efforts and dedication unnoticed by the reporting manager, with little to no recognition or appreciation from the management.
Over worked and a stressful work environment, not verry supportive management. Low salary.

Limited possibility to moove forward. Pay is not as high as other places. Providing opportunity and assistance to educate in your field of department, is although encouraged and claim to support, is actually not carried through when you request it.
For someone joining us from outside the industry you need to be curious and open to learning new things quickly. We work at a fast pace which can take a while to get used to.
Low pay, the management and culture is horrible. With the low pay they only retain sub standard management and anyone of value usually doesn’t last for more then 12/18 months.

High staff turnover. Limited growth opportunities. Most of team member underpaid after few years working here. Staff can be overburdened without sufficient support. Transformation team in place at moment lack of focus of loyalty staff

No flexible working arrangements Mixed messaging and conflicting direction from management. Departments can be very cliquey. Experienced disrespectful comments about my culture from some staff. Management gaslight you into thinking you are being paid well but it’s far below average pay.
Management, pay is average and they expect the absolute world from you.
Very fast paced industry. A lot happening with very conflicting timelines to get tasks completed.

The size and breadth of what they do is a double-edged sword. While ABN Group does a lot in the industry, the wide diversity of work and roles can cause a little confusion at times. But that's all part of a big company that continues to grow and evolve.
Environment is face paced, you won't have a problem if you work hard and enjoy a challenge, but this place isn't for someone wanting to sit back and be lazy.

Having to “fit in” so you don’t get constant management or HR meetings. The compulsory events for staff. The challenge of fitting in attending everything when you have a life makes it not a nice place to work. High staff turnover was a big issue. Most people leave after 12-18 months which meant more issues with clients due to inexperienced staff. I saw many people with experience leave and go to different companies with better incentives or rewards. The clashes between operations and sales. There are constantly issues between the two departments which makes the office environment sometimes stressful for staff. Having to work 7 days a week and manage a life outside of the company. Management micromanage and place extra pressure to achieve targets constantly moving the goal post. OVERALL it was a good learning experience just not somewhere one can build a career due to it being un-sustainable long-term for most people. I felt like it was a good learning experience for a young person at the beginning of their career.
High staff turnover at present

There's not necessarily anything 'difficult' here at ABN. Sure, the workloads are large but that's not a negative. Increased workloads is a great factor for the business plus we are very much supported here so you never feel like you're drowning. If you speak up, Management will jump straight away to offer assistance.
Like everyone lockdowns and restrictions made 2020 / 2021 challenging however ABN Group were ahead of the game making flexible work arrangements for staff.

I was warned about working for this company by a few people. I decided to take the offer and work for the company. Offer was made, I accepted, left my existing job.... 2 days before starting, I get a call and being told the offer was rescinded. No compensation was given, offered, or even considered. Basically told "oh well, deal with it"
It's a busy place to work with high customer expectations, you'll need to not be afraid of some hard work and roll your sleeves up at times.
Having to fit in so you dont get constant HR or management meetings.
Was challenging for me to learn about the volume building industry, but with support and training, it is now the only industry I would want to work in.
Very fast paced but I do like to be busy

Parking, that's about it!
greed of bosses pay to workers is very low its a struggle to live day to day

not enough desk space due to growing industry but they will be looking to increase

The customer is always right. Sometimes they're not!

Poor, inexperience and toxic behavior from direct/local management. Goal posts moved on daily basis with no consistency in being able to routinely work to meet these goals. Whilst flexible working arrangements were promoted, they didn't exist - no hybrid working model, requirement to be on site 4 days a week, ability to work at other sites reduced which resulted in the breakdown of working relationships with teams. Career advancement dependent on personal relationships with management.
Clueless management who are power driven.

management need to make faster decisions on changes

New systems that have been introduced are not working and have not been supported by upper management, head count reductions and restructuring is a constant normal activity that has now pushed the business and its culture to a poor state

IT Senior Management team decided to outsource IT Ops Support and lost too much experience, then the Management team left as well - go figure. No Management understanding of the risks associated with outsourcing core IT support in a Tightly Regulated Business only a push to meet KPI's for staff & cost reduction.

Inexperienced Management who have no idea about the Electricity Distribution Business. No new ideas just old ones recycled. Trying to implement new systems to replace ones that weren't broken and failing.
Ongoing meetings with no outcomes, short-term vision, lots of inner politics

I found working for Powercor itself was challenging in the nature of the projects we undertook. These challenges resulted in positive outcomes.
Dealing with the slow career development if you're driven
Every day is a challenge no same day.

Mostly irate people calling to let us know they had no power. A large portion were really needing to call their retailer as they had been disconnected due to non payment but the challenge was getting those people to understand that. Also when the smart meter was installed it was incredibly draining but the hours and the wages were well worth it. I would have loved permanent there but because it is seasonal work this was not possible or I would have still been with the company.
Opportunity to grow is quite limited. No ambition to improve further and relatively reluctant to take on other new opportunities
The management and poeple not open to new ideas or change
Bad managers

Male dominant work place as there's alot of tradies. As a female it was great because guys don't cause work place issues like females.

extremely political, below average salary, expectation to work over time as a norm, no recognition of any sort, outdated system, whole business still runs like its in the 1800s, favouritism is rampant, upper management restructuring whenever they get bored, shocking boomer mentality to solve any issues

Cross-Department Communication Sometimes there are gaps in communication between teams like design, production, and logistics. Miscommunication can cause delays or rework. Balancing Speed with Quality The push for fast delivery can sometimes make it hard to maintain high craftsmanship standards. It requires strong attention to detail and time management Career Development Some employees feel unsure about how to progress or upskill within the company. More structured training programs or mentorship could help. Recognition and Feedback While the culture is generally positive, more regular recognition for hard work would boost motivation. Simple things like shout-outs or team awards could go a long way.
Like every workplace there are lots of challenges. Company has gone through a structural change that is not always simple. Don't always have career growth option.
Some systems outdated, but always improving
Every company has its challenges, and Fleetwood is no different. They do clearly show a genuine commitment to making ongoing improvements.

Like any company, Fleetwood has its challenges. The difference now is that management is owning those issues and putting real effort into making changes. It's not perfect, but it's moving in the right direction and its a good time to be part of that.
some it can be challenging

Opportunities for growth within the company are currently limited, and work acknowledgment could be strengthened. No official team-bonding activities have been held, and celebrations are minimal, usually taking place at only one location. Hybrid work arrangements are available only with formal approval.
Difficult to Increase Salary or Promotion. Any position above documenter is generally underpaid Long periods of high demand workloads, short time frames little recognition for good work - No bonuses

All businesses have their challenges and Fleetwood is no different. the difference is that Fleetwood is aware of and actively fixing its flaws. Systems can be lacking in some areas, and work is being done to improve this.

All east coast operations are managed out of Melbourne resulting in inefficient processes. The managers are slow to respond and have no understanding of the different markets in Qld. I was not allowed to work with with staff that sat 5m away from me. I had to pass project related questions through the Melbourne office. Just ridiculous. They constantly prioritise their own projects over those in Qld. There is no opportunity for advancement in this company.

The General Manager is a micro manager and lacks people skills. The Brisbane office is managed by the Melbourne office and it is a frustrating set up with no one in the Brisbane office having any authority to make decisions or changes. The expectation is for you to work long hours past your 40 hour week however frown upon or expect you make up any time you need to have off. It was a very tense environment at times.

poor management, unrealistic workloads, people in roles they really shouldn't be

Declining industry - printing is in decline and Spicers core business is the marketing & sale of paper products into the sheet-cut printing industry. While they do have a large business selling into the wide format and signage industry this is not core. They have mainly built this through acquisition, they acquire these businesses then try and represent themselves as trusted partners to sign makers and display houses but they are hardly that. I wouldn't trust anyone in this business.
It is a lot of repetitive work, day in and day out, and some workers constantly complain.

There are always plenty of things to learn - new product knowledge, new home building and construction know-how, industry updates.. etc. Being a frontline sales role, helping customers to bring their dream home to life requires lots of passion, patience and stamina.
Heavy but manageable workload. There is always plenty to do but you'll never get bored!

Management can never make up their minds. Staff are expected to stay back until 10pm to get work done that is given to them at 5pm. That is quite the unsafe walk to the carpark that is a while away. Lots of people running around like headless chooks and backflipping on direction. Incredibly stressful environment, people work through their lunches and are constantly burnt out. No future strategy. Half the team in Brisbane, half the team in Melbourne.. Meant to be working on the same goal but never on the same page and constantly arguing over who has a say. Lots of people who talk the talk with nothing to show.

Some longer hours and very busy periods with booms in the building industry, which then can flip to slow times when the building industry falls. The constant change of new products, replacing products can have its challenges.
The organisation has experienced rapid growth which brings with it constant changes to processes but I see this as a positive. It shows the organisation is adaptable.
the company is still somewhat small and therefore there may be less opportunities for growth in certain departments.

Culture is really poor, insular and you dont get treated the best at all. Wouldn't agree that's its a 'great place to work', rather get some experience and move on. Only challenges would be the weather, hot days are usually fine if you start early, routes on average are about 5 and a half hours so if you start at the recommended time of 7am the weather hasn't reached its peak by the time you finish, and tines can be flexible on some occasions you can do an hour the next day to catch up when the weather is better. Every day that is not overly hot or wet is quite nice to be around. A small price to pay for all the positives the job brings for a young person.

Management are very unprofessional, rude and non transparent. There is a lack of communication, experience and safety procedures. Not many people that work there are happy. Avoid this place at all costs. You will be treated poorly.

Project execution is being undermined by poor PM planning, limited senior management engagement or over the top interferance, and inadequate PMO team experience. Decision making prioritises push run rates and short-term returns over resources and requirements essential for safe, effective field delivery. This results in suboptimal setups, insufficient lead times, increased risks to schedule, quality, and safety. Accountability is frequently shifted onto middle managers, supervisors, and field staff, while senior management avoid responsibility for gaps in professionalism and project management capability. Rather than addressing the causes, issues are concealed or removed from reporting, fostering a culture of avoidance. The workplace culture is toxic, with subjugation and mutual protection among managers when deficiencies are exposed. Risk and issue reports are often dismissed, HR and HSE fail to provide adequate support to middle and lower-level managers raising legitimate concerns.
Lack of knowledge and supervisor Unrealistic expectations for new employees Unclear structure and outdated WMS system Untidy and risky warehouse

One thing I don’t enjoy as much is dealing with repetitive or unclear documentation from subcontractors or external teams. It can slow down delivery and create unnecessary back-and-forth when expectations aren’t clearly met. I prefer working in environments where accountability is strong and processes are streamlined, so when issues pop up due to poor coordination or incomplete handovers, I find it frustrating—but also motivating. That’s usually when I step in to refine documentation, improve training, or introduce feedback loops to get things back on track.

Poor senior management, No Training provided. No senior management support and they certainly don't value staff only see people as number no matter their experience in the industry. A large business with a poor HR system which provides no support to any people manager.
Over work you, under pay you. Terrible management and all for themselves. You are just a number. Will tell you one thing do another. No support for employees.

Management was the #1 issue. Continuous poor & contradictory communication, no accountability - everything is your fault, useless training then thrown in the deep end, constant monitoring/calling to pester and demean you, no matter what you do it's wrong. You can see why Ventia and Downer have higher satisfaction scores. The supporting departments are not helping. Seemed that the routes, estimated completion times, rules, kpi's etc. were designed by a different company using poor data. Service Stream have been contracted to complete the work; and must meet the other company's kpi's to keep the contract. $$ -Unrealistic expectations. Each day you could be assigned x2 routes, several km's apart comprising of 270-ish meters with estimated completion times of 3 hours. (Kpi is a minimum of 80 reads per hour). -Tripping hazards, Dog P**, expectation to work in all weather conditions. -Unclear, abbreviated instructions to locate meters. -Hidden meters in retail shops, medical clinics, churches, sporting clubs, schools. -Poor sequencing of routes resulting in back tracking, inevitably arousing suspicion from general public, obstructed meters, daily check in phone calls, getting questioned about why you skipped/couldn't read a meter, being warned you might need to travel back to an address to correct/re-attempt a read, being told you're working too slowly. -They'll say there's usually Public Loo's enroute but there's not. High likelihood you'll relieve yourself in bottles/behind bushes/in vacant lots. -Fortnightly pay -To get paid properly, you have to manually record all your day's work. And outside work hours, type it into a timesheet and send to payroll. -All this for casual work $1 above Minimum Wage
High Stress, High Work loads, Challenging clients

The WMC will issue work to family members (contractors) before employees, even though management teams them directly otherwise.

Some meter locations/properties can be hazardous for a variety of different reasons, and the job is unpleasant in extremely hot or wet weather conditions. Allocated routes can be extremely disorganized, and meter location information is often outdated or inaccurate; even GPS coordinates can be unreliable. This means you'll regularly double-back to streets you've already been to pick up reads that are out of sequence and go on wild goose-chases looking for meter locations. In a role where time is of the essence and KPIs need to be met, this level of disorder can make the job frustrating at times.

Despite its public image, the internal culture is highly hierarchical and driven by informal power structures. In my experience, inappropriate behaviour was not only tolerated but, at times, protected through silence and non-disclosure agreements. Career progression was often influenced by personal affiliations rather than merit. Staff are given personal and inappropriate ‘career advice’ from senior management. Raising concerns about this led to exclusion from meetings, withholding of critical information, and public undermining. When issues were raised with HR, the response leaned toward risk minimisation rather than meaningful support, with formal action discouraged due to likely duration, mental health impact, and low chance of resolution.

Management is about 50% terrible. Staff safety and morale are no where near a priority. Management will enforce very random small rules, but will not actually train staff, or reprimand anyone that is not doing their actual job. This means that if you have good work ethic, you will run yourself into the ground trying to do other people's jobs and get no recognition for it. Uniform changes on managements whim, and it's your job to go and buy the new uniform each time. Every other hospo worker gets 20% off everything at the Brunny, except for the people that actually work there, they get to pay full price. You, as an employee, are not important to management. How management look to head office, and how much management can get as a bonus, is the priority. If you try and input any ideas they will, at best, be stolen. There is no support from management with anything. They will question any decision. If you want to work somewhere where you are treated like a child, have very little actual opportunity to grow, and can get away with doing the bare minimum, this is the one for you!

I’ve worked in a lot of places over the years, and this company reminds me of the bad old days. Management is far too controlling and there’s no real leadership to speak of. Promotions and reviews don’t go to the people who put in the hard work, but to the favorites who know how to talk and stay on the right side of the bosses. The folks doing the real graft get overlooked. Projects are messy, tasks unclear, and you’re ALWAYS left to figure things out on your own. There’s no training, no coaching, and no thought about helping people grow a career here. On top of that, it’s a very male-heavy environment, where I hardly saw any women in staff or leadership roles, which feels outdated in this day and age. My honest advice: don’t join this company by any means.

My experience working on the Westgate Tunnel Project was extremely negative. The work environment was toxic, with direct management displaying unprofessional and disrespectful behavior, including inappropriate actions in the office. There was a serious lack of accountability and focus on productivity, with time wasted without delivering meaningful results. Unfortunately, the Fotscarey HR team was aware of these issues but took no clear action, leaving the situation unresolved. Leadership failed to address these problems, creating a stressful and demotivating atmosphere. I would not recommend this project to anyone seeking a professional and supportive workplace.

Unfortunately, my time at UGL was marked by a complete lack of support, ineffective leadership, and a toxic culture that did not value employee wellbeing. This culture enabled unacceptable treatment of employees, with little to no concern for their mental health, wellbeing or professional respect.

The RAAF AMB team is marked by a consistently challenging and negative work environment under its current supervisor and management. There is no opportunity for career progression, minimal overtime availability, and a poorly structured roster that disregards work-life balance. Cost-cutting measures, such as adjusting start times to avoid paying penalty rates, further contribute to employee dissatisfaction. Additionally, the supervisor often offers higher-duty positions only to revoke them without any notice or direct communication. Employees typically find out about these changes through others, adding to a lack of transparency and trust.

I want to thank BGIS for removing my review on Director of IT's toxic leadership, misconducts, hostility, favoritism, harrassing, disrespectful, unprofessional conduct that has led to many resignations. I also mentioned in my review about IT Management as a whole, how toxic it is. I spoke not only for myself, but for current and former employees. My review was based on factual occurrences and not personal grievances. This shows that this is a company wide issue, BGIS has swept it under the rug. By removing the review, it tells me the inaction and unaccountability on the director and IT management. I even escalated all these problems all the way up to global, but by deleting this review, I now understand BGIS's true intent and colours- which is to protect senior leadership at any cost. Just do not ever work for this company please, they have no problem to sacrifice employee well-being to shield toxic leadership. Their solution is EAP and not actually taking accountability and action to remove the problem. Even though I have been so professional, giving you the benefit of the doubt, but now, BGIS, you have truly are a disappointment. Anyone who is looking to apply for this role, just don't, you'll be working under the Director of IT and they are here to stay- BGIS will take zero accountability. Go for a company that actually values its employees and has zero tolerance for favoring toxic senior leadership.

Management in BGIS Self perform was an absolute joke, no trade experience and refuse to take on advice from experienced tradesmen. Certificates of compliance were not signed off for months on end (even when brought to attention) as an electrical supervisor was never put in place since the last one left. Everyone is “put under the same blanket” where even if you are an above and beyond worker it will only take one other person in the team being slack to be put in a meeting and everyone be labeled as a poor worker by the Australian Self perform manager. Important issues such as lvr/cpr training out of date will be completely ignored by management unless brought up in a meeting with a client present. (7 staff members have left in past 2 months)

This company is a bad employer. They offer no support or development. It feels like you are simply a worker drone to them. Management don’t look after hard workers as they feel threatened by their knowledge and skill set. Huge turn over of staff! So you will spend most of your days covering for those that leave or get the boot and then have to train the next person who usually is gone within a couple of months so it is a cycle you can not help or keep up with when your own workload is so high. Work loads with unrealistic deadlines get dropped on you when you are already so inundated and if you request support you will be told no and that the request is fair and reasonable. Roles and responsibilities will be changed overnight without any formal communication or support, you will be expected to just know that discussions have taken place with management and things have changed or u hear it via gossip from other team members. Majority of the time different instructions are given to team members of the same position causing confusion and frustration, this was usually followed with discipline to the team member for not being a mind reader.

Nepotism (with a dash of r@cism) - because some people are able to go from outsiders to managers straightaway, even if they don't have the relevant education nor experience. Some managers behave like psychopaths who enjoy controlling, micomanaging and humiliating employees. They lie, change rules on a whim (even going against directive), drop unexpected workloads, giving misdirections on tasks, contradicting each other and themselves, are uncaring towards any issue raised by staff, clients, and customers. Going to work feels like walking on eggshells because you'd never know if you are suddenly picked on due to some mistake you made days ago - even if you've been doing the same things as everyone else. If the managers feel challenged by you, they'd use their position to smear your name to the higher-ups, and they'd do it during work hours so that you are publicly shamed. God forbid you have a rough day, or terrible workplace encounter, because your emotions and feelings are seen as invalid and irrelevant.

Your experience will also vary depending on what team you land in and what manager/supervisor you get. I've had nothing but positive leadership experiences and have had a chance to work with some really exceptional leaders but I have also observed some less than desirable leadership behaviours in other teams from long-standing employees which unfortunately doesn't appear to be addressed, excused with an attitude of "that's just how they are". Its no longer the old Leighton Contractors, it seems that almost everyone putting together a major project hard dollar tender is a consultant or casual employee, if you a casual employee, who in there right mind would argue if the tender documentation is incorrect, or argue with someone higher up is wanting to win the project at all costs, and woe be tied anyone below them says there's not enough geotechnical data, perhaps the office admin support staff are CPB permanent employees, no desk phones in the tender office! must use your BYO mobile, stationary for the office BYO, that practice is cheap considering the client is reimbursing tendering costs, with so many temporary staff putting together big hard dollar tenders does it come to any real surprise you hear them taking a big hit on tunnel projects and just relying on the contract penalty provisions when it all gets too hard, this sort of business model is rather finite and I think the Spainards know it,

Star Rating: We don't have enough reviews for Hickory yet to show an average rating.

Review Text: The flip-side would be that there are unrealistic work-load expectations placed on the team, which was very short-staffed for a commercial team. This created a demanding work environment as staff were asked to undertake tasks and responsibilities well-outside their roles to make-up for the lack of numbers (i.e. a Site Foreman, a Safety Officer, a Site Engineer / Cadet, etc.). With regards to contract administration and design coordination, I personally felt that there was a lot of unnecessary risk taken on from a Head Contractor. Additionally, through my experiences on the project, communicating, coordinating and receiving information from our own suppliers in China for prefabricated structural and façade elements was beyond difficult (much easier to deal with external subcontractors). Between supervising works on-site & day-to-day site tasks and the coordination & administration side of things in the office, an 80-hour minimum working week is the norm here (6 days a week mandatory). This realistically cannot be sustained. The main reason I decided to resign was the way the company handled the coronavirus pandemic back in mid-March 2020 - half the team was placed on standby for approximately 3 months and additionally there was a freeze on hiring much needed site staff. This was despite the project moving forward at a greater pace (as Council DA hours were extended). Talking with colleagues from previous companies, this was not the case at their workplace.

While there are some positive aspects to the role, my experience was impacted by several ongoing issues. There were frequent interruptions to personal time off through WhatsApp, which made it difficult to maintain a healthy work-life balance. The heavy focus on KPIs often led to unpaid overtime, as meeting expectations during regular hours was unrealistic. Upper management appeared unreceptive to feedback, continuing to increase demands without addressing existing concerns. Additionally, the compensation does not reflect the responsibilities of the role, particularly for full-time staff and those in leadership positions.

Teaching CGEA I and II to Australian school leavers with diverse needs and age groups was challenging. Students came with different levels of literacy, motivation, and personal circumstances, which made lesson planning complex. As a casual teacher, limited time and resources sometimes made it difficult to provide consistent support. Some students faced barriers such as trauma, mental health issues, or unstable housing, which affected their engagement. Improving access to personalised learning support, offering regular professional development for staff, and strengthening collaboration with student services could help address these challenges. More structured pathways for students transitioning from school to adult education would also support better engagement and outcomes.

Burwood Cattery - seniors have zero faith in their staff, you have to ask permission to do any tiny little thing rather than use your own critical thinking and decision making abilities. Very tight fisted with who they select to train in the 'more difficult' areas of cattery even if you have prior experience. This creates a hierarchy within even the casual staff and makes opportunities to learn and develop skills a very slow process, if it happens for you at all. This treatment made me question my abilities and reduced my confidence in my job significantly, and was incredibly bad for my anxiety. They prefer seniors to have at least ~12 years experience, so if you're relatively new to the industry you have no chance for upward mobility. The cattery itself is in the very bottom of the building, tucked away in what used to be old offices. Very cramped, dark and unpleasant, all the cats in shoreline cages, even in the flu and ringworm rooms. Heating and cooling constantly breaking down. Not a nice working environment.

Management of their libraries clearly out of their depth where proper management and understanding of staff resources are concerned. The red tape is unbelievable, any change (even small ones) takes months, years even. No transparency in processes. Ongoing inequity in work roster allocation. Disrespectful of their casual staff pool. Council leadership either unaware or if they are, couldn't be bothered to investigate as survey results show their libraries performing well in customer satisfaction (but that is due to those staff on the front line that are hardworking, principled and responsible doing the hard work), definitely not the result of management efforts although management gets the recognition and rewards. Very political at the top, management too busy protecting their own jobs and backs to be effective to actually 'manage'. If you can talk the talk and polish up the 'management' and are happy to let others do the work when 'management' is not there to see, this is the place for you to get rewarded with continuous secondment and promotion opportunities. If you are hardworking and hopeful for recognition and career advancement ON MERIT, this is not the place for you.

Procurement roles here are very challenging. Management recruitment often feels misaligned, which impacts decision-making quality. The business is consistently 5–6 years behind on policy compliance, with limited work instructions beyond basic VGPB requirements. Employees are often left to independently interpret and implement policies, only to find months later — when tasks or projects are nearly complete and awaiting final approval — that their work is overridden, requiring them to start again from scratch. Senior management tends not to proactively engage with policy changes and only react when problems occur, often shifting accountability instead of addressing core causes. Coordination and planning across the company are weak, with directions frequently ambiguous and major shifts in focus every six months.

The procurement leadership lacks clear direction, professionalism, and the necessary experience and qualifications. The executive team often changes priorities without effective communication, causing widespread confusion and frustration across the organization (look at the revolving door of staff).
Salary not comparable compared with industry although no expectation of overtime.

Management is reactionary and act in a knee-jerk manner. Commission structure is largely unachievable based on the typical leads provided unless you're at one of the 3 top performing stores. Then you're blamed for not achieving this target. As a result there's an extremely high turnover of employees as people begin to see the reality. They will make employees redundant for not meeting the (mostly impossible) sales targets yet still have an active and seemingly permanent hiring advertisement here on Seek. You can try your hardest and do the best you can with the leads provided, dealing with client problems, but it's not enough. All that matters is the G.P you bring in.

There were ongoing issues with timesheet accuracy and wage concerns that were difficult to get resolved. Staff were often expected to check and respond to messages outside of rostered hours, leaving little ability to properly disconnect. HR and management appeared to have a limited understanding of employment law, and staff often had to push to have even basic entitlements respected. Communication between head office and stores was very poor, and decisions were made without awareness of store operations. Stock delays and damaged deliveries were common, frustrating both staff and customers; the worst delay during my time there was around eight weeks, which significantly impacted customer satisfaction and store operations. Understaffing and tight budgets created stress, with most store roles paid close to minimum wage. Almost all non-management staff were casual, and incentives were minimal compared to company profits.

The hours are painful, you get told at the induction availability must be 24/7 but you get rostered a min of 19hours, Even if you want less hours there is so much red tape around swapping out a shift. Ask to see the roster in advance, depending on what airline you will learn 1st, the hours can and will take a massive toll on you, esp the split shifts. You could day 8/9 days in a row and have 8/9 splits shifts. No penalties,double time or time + 1/2. No staff travel. The ability to take annual leave is also out of the question, you have to apply early or otherwise risk not getting leave when its requested. The company expect to pretty much do with you what they like as long as its legal, min 10 hours between shifts. No duty of care towards staff, No balance at all, No set or rotating roster, rosters are posted 2 weeks in advance , maybe even 3 weeks ahead (no ability to plan life outside of work). Working in an airport environment is tough, if you are looking for family friendly,balanced lifestyle, fairness & equal opportunity, this is not the place for you. Expect to work yourself to the bone without much thanks or appreciation and people are treated like numbers here. We are all replaceable.Staff turnover is huge and Menzies do not have the ability to keep experienced staff. If the company improved their core values maybe things would change.

My time at FedEx was challenging—not because of the work itself, which was manageable and straightforward—but due to poor management practices. I was consistently overworked, underpaid, and experienced issues with altered timesheets, which affected my compensation. Promised training was either inadequate or never delivered, leaving employees to figure things out on their own. Unfortunately, the lack of support and accountability from leadership made the work environment stressful and frustrating.

It all goes down to management + systems. The level of micromanagement, personal callouts/hunting, blame shifting and favouritism fosters a negative, toxic working environment. You may do very well at your job, but you will only truly thrive if you're liked by the supervisors or are within the "in" group. Inappropriate comments were something they have done on many instances and the level of unprofessionalism have gotten under my skin several times. If you had feedback or constructive criticisms to share to help improve and streamline the workflow, they will stick to what they believe is right, because someone 20-30 years ago said so. People who have been wonderful have left this workplace for many reasons. The very moment I walked out of here, I felt like I was healing.

90 hour fortnightly roster for average pay. The store leaks in the rain and the staff facilities are awful. Broken taps and no decent drinking water for staff. The heating is awful and you have to park your car on the main road. No chairs in the store so you're on your feet 9 to 11 hours a day depending on the shift you have. Sales targets don't add up too the realistic trade that the store achieves. Some times no customers enter the store for hours at a time so be prepared to be bored , unless the state manager is present then everyone tries to look busy. You might be sent to get change from the bank or pick up stock or deliver items to customers using your car with no compensation. Once every week or so the sight gets an email from above to go spy on the local competition so you get sent to take pictures and report back. Training happens when you have no customers but it's the same 5 legend products. The business practice and return policies are awful , I could go on and on.
Store manager was a terrible manager with no people skills whatsoever. Hours also are not ideal if you have a family.

Like any fast-paced retail environment, Sydney Tools can be challenging at times. The workload can be demanding, especially during peak sales periods, and staying across such a large product range requires ongoing learning. Targets are ambitious, which pushes you to continually perform at your best. These challenges can be intense, but they also help you grow professionally, build resilience, and develop strong problem-solving skills. If you’re motivated, adaptable, and enjoy working under pressure, these aspects can actually be very rewarding.
No real challenges, as always, there are difficult situations that arise; however, management is always willing to support when required.

Expected to do 12+ hour days unpaid during EOFY period and all they offer is Time in lieu which is a struggle to use when you want to. You will be judged and scolded if your sales drop but when your doing constantly going over your target they say nothing. The procedure and policies the company implement are a joke and your forced to deal with angry customers who take it out on you even though the people who decide the policies never have to represent them in a store. This company does not care about you and only trying to scrape every cent out of a consumer. Work-Life Balance Can Vary: While flexibility exists, peak periods can be intense and demand long hours if you’re not managing your time well.

Sydney Tools can be a fast-paced and demanding environment, which might be overwhelming for some at first. There’s a lot to learn—from our extensive product range to the technical knowledge needed to assist tradespeople and customers effectively. However, the company provides strong in-store training and structured learning modules that make this very achievable with the right mindset. Like most retail businesses, weekend work is part of the role, as we operate seven days a week. This is something to be expected, but the effort you put in doesn’t go unnoticed—the company genuinely rewards dedication and hard work with real opportunities for advancement.

We primarily deliver air mattresses to hospitals across Sydney, but the workload can vary significantly depending on the area you’re assigned to. In major hospitals, the workload can be overwhelming — it keeps piling up with no signs of slowing down. Burnout can happen quickly, and unfortunately, raising concerns with HR or management rarely leads to any real change. Most of the time, I worked alone without much support. Communication often felt one-sided, with little acknowledgment or response. In some cases, you may even feel targeted, especially if you’re repeatedly assigned to certain hospitals with heavier demands. That said, I was fortunate to have some amazing colleagues who were supportive and helped me learn the ropes. Without them, the experience would’ve been much tougher. Sadly, hard work often goes unrecognized, and rewards or appreciation are rare. The constant drama in the workplace only adds to the stress. I hope for the better in the future.

• Constant low morale rhroughout the office. Everyone quietly acknowledges their misery while putting on a fake smile publicly. You're expexted to be positive all the time. • Perks being rescinded (flexible working arrangements & no pay rise mandate in April 2024). • People talk behind your back. • Little to no opportunities for development or department transfers deapite Development Dollars initiative. It's extremely hard to meet the criteria to acceas funding due to sparse scheduling of workshops you must attend and high workload not allowing you the time. • Department and Line management play favourites- you won't get promoted or recognised if you're not one. Even if you kiss a** and burn yourself out trying to prove yourself. • For a company who values "celebrating success", many hard working employees feel apathetic and frankly cynical because any recognition that is shared is just between office cliques. Not genuine at all. • Junior-Mid level employees are overworked, undervalued, and underpaid by industry standards. • Junior-Mid level employees train their frankly unqualified line managers and continually get taken advantage of for their good work ethic. • Mistakes and missed budgets are punished, you'll feel like dirt at times. Upper management and the board have some KPIs which are too high for a post-COVID, recession bound economy. Unfortunately MFG is becoming more of a toxic place to work each day. A fancy rebrand, new work "social media" platform, staff discounts, and free coffee (for now) isn't enough to raise morale or retain employees. Those things are nice, but they won't keep a roof over heads and they don't really help people feel that good about soming to work. There's just a lot of PR talk to make things seem like sunshine and rainbows but employees can see through the farse. Junior-Mid level employees should be paid more for all the things they endure. This is across all departments at head office, the DC, and retail stores. At this point, there's nothing to suggest. Being retail, this company exists to make a profit and unfortunately employyes suffer in order to make that happen. I hope they don't resort to redundancies to meet their targets. I sincerely hope things inprove at MFG, I've heard that employees used to think the culture was great and that they felt looked after. I never experienced that.

Very poor culture within the Glencore office in Perth (co-located within the same building as Murrin Murrin). The office is extremely outdated, with minimal or no facilities expected of a global organisation. Supply Chain, where I worked, has significant levels of micro management - and the managers have rewarded people who promote this culture. There has been excessive turnaround within both teams with management continuing to blame the environment, where in reality a clean sweep of the culture and lead team is required. There is no diversity or focus on safety and many have come and gone within the space of 12 months. Whilst Glencore may look “appealing” from the website, the brochures and the advertising, I implore you to think twice before joining. There is a reason people don’t stay more than 12 months. Having rejoined the industry at a big Australian major, I now realise I should have left earlier. Do not recommend.

Review Text: There were a lot of students who came from a background where English was not their first language so sometimes you needed to really modify work and tasks to make it more suitable for them. This is very important however it could also be quite time-consuming.

At the time I was there: Staff were highly micromanaged There was no self-care for staff Discipline was tough with uniform but not much else and turned a blind eye to serious repeat behaviours Arts was treated as a child-minding subject with very little investment in developing student self-expression through drama, dance or music and there was the expectation of 18 or more students in senior (Year 11 or 12) performing arts classes (!)- so they did not run because they would never get that number Large Chaldean population with refugee background - should be offering an Arabic language - to be more global but leadership afraid to embrace this suggestion Need to show more respect to women teachers

One of the main challenges in a Continuous Improvement role is resistance to change. Sometimes, even when data clearly shows the benefits, people may be hesitant to adopt new processes. While this can be frustrating, I see it as an opportunity to strengthen my communication and stakeholder engagement skills by listening, addressing concerns, and showing the value of improvements. Another challenge is that results often take time to become visible, which can test patience. However, I’ve learned to celebrate small wins along the way and keep momentum going until the bigger impact is achieved

The company did not have an effective performance management system. The company did not take effort to monitor achievements of individual Supervisors nor any performance review conducted for supervisors. Sometimes the Supervisors were more focussed on their own performance and fail to see the larger picture and play team role. The company spent more than two million dollars per year (other than the insurance amount) on workplace health and safety for monitoring, conducting audits, risk assessments etc. It conducted safety audit almost every two weeks covering every nook and corner of the factory, but When a major near miss accident happened instead of taking collective responsibility for failure to recognise the risk, the company destroyed the career of the individual supervisor in charge of the area to set an example. It finally got rid of the supervisor on flimsy ground. After the plant level restructure a cohesive culture has formed within the junior management level, which in order to maintain the cohesive culture is failing to challenge shortcomings within the team.

The company has lost its humanity. While some areas stay true to its core values, the business side of the company has become very corporate. Since moving to the city 3 years ago, pretty much all senior managers were either asked to go or shortly left of their own accord. They have been replaced with people from a predominantly financial background. This has resulted in business strategies more akin to profit making than for a mutual, member based company. 'Member benefits' is constantly bandied around but there is little improvement in the offer. While I agree with the overall direction for which RACV is aiming, there is a distinct lack of specific planning and vision. No one really knows how we are going to get there. Workers are given broad and vague goals and when things don't work, there is another restructure. There has been little significant change since the new CEO started over 4 years ago.
Its hard to change the old RACV mentality even when they say they want to change, as higher management has been there so long they unfortunately know no different

Overly Bureaucratic Processes: Excessive red tape and rigid procedures slow down decision-making and hinder innovation. Poor Communication: Lack of transparency and ineffective communication channels between teams and management. Limited Growth Opportunities: Few clear pathways for career advancement or professional development. Micromanagement: A culture where employees’ work is overly scrutinised, leading to decreased autonomy and trust. Resistance to Change: An unwillingness to adapt to new ideas, technologies, or methods, leaving the organisation stagnant. Low Employee Morale: A demotivating environment caused by lack of recognition, support, or engagement initiatives. Favouritism or Nepotism: Unequal treatment of employees, creating a sense of unfairness and frustration. High Turnover Rates: Frequent employee departures, often due to dissatisfaction with the work environment. Siloed Teams: Departments or teams that operate in isolation, leading to inefficiencies and lack of collaboration. Lack of Innovation: A focus on maintaining the status quo rather than fostering creativity or forward-thinking approaches. Overemphasis on Hierarchy: A rigid hierarchy where decision-making power is concentrated at the top, limiting employees’ ability to contribute ideas or take initiative.
Destructive colleagues and management no matter how hard you work and advise the right things.

Over time at City, working conditions have steadily declined despite the continued promotion of “flexible work arrangements.” Policies have shifted from fully remote during the pandemic to increasingly rigid in-office requirements and stricter hours, even for teams without external stakeholders. Employee surveys are conducted regularly, but meaningful changes rarely follow, with leadership focusing on minor fixes rather than core issues. Decision-making at the senior level often appears inconsistent, with resources allocated unevenly and new roles created for select individuals, which can foster perceptions of favoritism. Overall, the organization struggles with reduced flexibility, questionable resource management, and a lack of transparency, all of which risk impacting employee morale and retention.

The real problem lies in the management culture. There’s a strong sense of disconnection between management and the people actually doing the work. Many decisions seem to be made by people who haven’t set foot on a site in years, yet they dictate how things should be done without understanding the realities or constraints technicians face. Instead of collaboration and support, there’s often a culture of blame and micromanagement. Some managers are more focused on politics, covering themselves, or chasing numbers than supporting their teams. Raising issues or suggesting improvements can easily get you labelled as “negative” rather than being taken seriously. This kind of toxic environment wears people down and drives away good technicians.

Review Text: The systems and work are a mess, the systems they’re using are outdated and slow. You get no support or training.

Toxic workplace with poor leadership and excessive micromanagement. A particular coordinator fails to support the team and delays planning report reviews, yet blames staff and expects constant reminders to do his job. Planners must attend site visits for nearly every application, adding to workload, while delays are never acknowledged by management. Flexible work arrangements exist in name only. They benefit management, not staff. Band 5 planners are limited to one work-from-home day per week, assigned at management’s discretion with no flexibility. Even then, staff must seek permission in advance to take their RDO. The coordinator focuses solely on KPIs, not team wellbeing, and morale is low. Staff turnover is very high. Salaries are advertised with super, misleading new planners about actual pay.
